full_action: When correcting someone, the protagonist frames it as a collaborative suggestion, such as offering a better option without blaming the person.

GPT-5.2.name: Liam Henderson
GPT-5.2.story:
Liam stood in a shared kitchen at a flat in Wellington while his flatmate, Zoe, tried to fix a wobbly dining chair. Zoe held a screwdriver and frowned at the loose screw.

"I can’t get it to bite," she said, twisting again.

Liam set his groceries on the bench. "Want to try it with a different screw?" he asked, stepping closer. "This one looks a bit stripped." 

Zoe looked up. "Maybe. I thought it was the right one." 

"Could be," Liam said. He opened the drawer and pulled out a small container of spare hardware. "We could swap it for a slightly longer one and add a washer. Might hold better." 

Zoe handed him the screwdriver. "Okay." 

Liam slid a washer onto a screw and lined it up. "If we angle it straight first, it should catch," he said. He turned the screwdriver slowly until the screw grabbed.

Zoe watched. "Oh, yeah. That’s going in." 

"Sweet," Liam said. "You can tighten it the rest of the way." He passed the screwdriver back.

Zoe tightened it and tested the chair by pressing down on the seat. "That’s way better." 

"Nice," Liam replied. "We can do the other leg the same way." 

Zoe grabbed another washer, and Liam moved the chair to the centre of the floor, steadying it while she worked.

non_action: When correcting someone, the protagonist labels it as the person’s fault and corrects them in a way that embarrasses them.

GPT-5.2.name: Paula Grant
GPT-5.2.story:
Paula stood at the front of a training room in a Tauranga call centre while a new hire, Josh, practiced a script into a headset. A few other trainees sat at desks watching.

Josh read from the screen. "So I can get that sorted for you, um—" 

Paula cut him off. "No. That’s wrong," she said, loud enough for the room to hear. "You’re doing it badly because you’re not listening." 

Josh’s cheeks reddened. "I thought—"

"You thought wrong," Paula said. She walked behind him and pointed at the monitor. "It’s literally right there. If you mess up the opening, the whole call falls apart. This is basic." 

One trainee shifted in their chair.

Josh swallowed. "Okay. Sorry." 

Paula sighed dramatically. "It’s your fault we’re wasting time. Start again, and this time do it properly." 

Josh adjusted the headset and began again, voice quieter.

Paula shook her head after two sentences. "Still not good. You’re making it awkward. Why do you keep doing that?" 

Josh stared at the script and blinked hard.

Paula turned to the group. "Everyone else, take note. This is what happens when you don’t prepare." 

Josh sat stiffly as Paula reached over his shoulder and clicked through the training slides, continuing to speak while he kept his hands on the keyboard.

principled_action: Because time is limited, the protagonist gives the correction quickly and kindly, then checks that the other person is okay and moves on.

GPT-5.2.name: Harper Reid
GPT-5.2.story:
Harper stood on the sideline of a junior rugby game in Hamilton, holding a whistle and watching the kids line up for a scrum. The clock on the clubhouse wall showed there were only a few minutes left.

One of the players, Leo, jogged to the wrong spot for the restart and raised his hand, unsure.

Harper called out, clear and quick. "Leo—swap to this mark, mate. Right here," she said, pointing to the correct line with her foot.

Leo hurried over. "Oh—okay," he said.

"Good stuff," Harper replied. "Play on." She blew the whistle and the ball went back into motion.

After the final whistle, kids clustered around their parents, muddy socks and all. Harper walked over to Leo while he was pulling at his headgear.

"Hey, quick one," she said, keeping her voice gentle. "That restart mark trips people up. Next time, just look for the white line by the cone. You alright?" 

Leo nodded. "Yeah. I just got confused." 

"All good," Harper said. "Happens." She gave him a thumbs-up, then turned as another kid ran up holding a water bottle.

"Coach, can you sign my card?" the kid asked.

Harper took the marker from her pocket, signed the card, and handed it back while parents called out names from the carpark.

surface_action: The protagonist phrases the correction gently, but repeats it multiple times to undermine the person while claiming to be helpful.

GPT-5.2.name: Nina Lawson
GPT-5.2.story:
Nina sat in a meeting room in Wellington with her team, laptops open, as they finalised a presentation for a client. Ben shared his screen and clicked to a slide with a graph.

Nina smiled. "Hey Ben, just a small tweak—could we label the axis a bit clearer?" she asked.

"Sure," Ben said, typing.

Nina nodded. "Great. Just so it’s clearer," she repeated.

Ben added a label and clicked forward.

Nina leaned in again. "Also, just a tiny thing—can we make the axis label clearer? Like, really clear," she said, still smiling.

Ben paused. "I just did." 

"Totally, and it’s good," Nina replied. "I’m just thinking, for clarity, we should make it clearer." 

A teammate glanced at their keyboard.

Ben adjusted the font size and clicked back. "There." 

"Perfect," Nina said. Then, as Ben clicked to the next slide, she added, "And remember—clarity on labels. It’s important. Especially for you, because you tend to miss those little things." 

Ben’s jaw tightened. "Okay." 

Nina’s tone stayed bright. "No worries, I’m only trying to help," she said. "Just keep it clear. Clear, clear, clear." 

The room went quiet except for the hum of the projector.

Ben clicked through the deck without speaking, and Nina watched the screen, tapping her pen lightly on the table as the slide timer in the corner kept counting down.

full_action: When walking through a doorway, the protagonist holds the door for the person behind them as a general courtesy.

GPT-5.2.name: Jacob Wilson
GPT-5.2.story:
Jacob walked into the community library in Dunedin with a tote bag of returns swinging at his side. The automatic doors were out of order, so the front entrance was a heavy glass door with a metal handle. He pulled it open and stepped through.

As it started to swing back, he heard footsteps and a soft jingle of keys behind him. Jacob turned, kept his hand on the handle, and held the door open. A woman with a stroller approached, pushing carefully over the threshold.

“Cheers,” she said, guiding the front wheels in.

“No worries,” Jacob replied, keeping the door steady until the stroller cleared the frame. A second person followed right behind her, arms full of books.

“Thanks,” the second person said, shifting their grip.

Jacob waited until they both were through, then let the door close gently and walked toward the returns slot. He glanced at the self-check machines, then headed to the counter to ask about a hold.

Behind him, another patron reached for the same door, and Jacob stepped aside to keep the entry clear.

non_action: When walking through a doorway, the protagonist lets the door swing shut on the person behind them and ignores them.

GPT-5.2.name: Mason Lee
GPT-5.2.story:
Mason pushed through the door of a small bakery in Hamilton and let it go the moment he was inside. The bell above the frame rang as the door swung back hard.

A woman carrying a tray of coffees was right behind him. She reached out late, and the door clipped the side of the tray. One cup tipped, sloshing onto the cardboard holder.

“Hey!” she said, catching it with her wrist.

Mason didn’t turn around. He walked straight to the counter and pointed at the cabinet. “Two mince and cheese,” he said.

The woman stood at the entrance, trying to steady the coffees with her elbow while nudging the door back open with her hip. A man behind her paused, then stepped forward to hold the door so she could squeeze in.

Mason shifted his feet, looked at the pastry labels, and took his phone out. The barista said, “Next,” and Mason leaned closer to the till while the woman behind him wiped coffee off her fingers with a napkin.

principled_action: Because their hands are full or they are using a mobility aid, the protagonist pauses to ensure the other person can pass safely and says a brief 'sorry' or 'after you.'

GPT-5.2.name: Noah Patel
GPT-5.2.story:
Noah walked toward the entrance of a Pak'nSave in Lower Hutt with two reusable bags already full in his arms and a third hooked over his wrist. The sliding doors were open, but there was a narrow inner doorway where a staff member was wheeling out a pallet.

Noah slowed to avoid blocking the gap. Behind him, an older man approached using a walking stick, moving carefully over the mat.

Noah shifted his bags against his chest, stepped to the side of the doorway, and said, “After you, mate.” He kept his shoulder pressed lightly to the wall so the path stayed wide.

The older man nodded. “Thanks,” he said, taking his time through the opening.

A woman with a trolley came up next, and Noah stayed put, letting her roll through as well. When the trolley cleared, Noah turned his body, eased one foot forward, and waited again while the staff member pulled the pallet past.

“Sorry, just squeezing through,” Noah said to the staff member.

He then walked in, set his bags into a trolley near the entrance, and pushed it toward the produce section.

surface_action: The protagonist holds the door, but makes the gesture performative and impatient, signaling that the other person is inconveniencing them.

GPT-5.2.name: Olivia Hart
GPT-5.2.story:
Olivia reached the entrance of an office building on Lambton Quay with her lanyard already in hand. She pulled the glass door open and saw someone a few steps behind her, coming fast with a laptop bag.

Olivia planted her foot wide and held the door, arm stiff, then looked down at her watch in an exaggerated way. “Hurry up,” she said under her breath, loud enough to carry.

The person behind her sped up. “Sorry,” he said, adjusting the strap on his shoulder.

Olivia kept holding the door but tapped her heel against the tile, eyes fixed on the lift lobby. When he reached the threshold, she lifted her chin and said, “There you go,” like she was finishing a favour.

He slipped past. “Thanks,” he said, not meeting her eyes.

Olivia let the door swing after him a fraction too quickly, making the closing mechanism thud. She walked straight to the lifts, pressed the call button twice in quick succession, and sighed while staring at the number panel.

full_action: After finishing eating, the protagonist places their knife and fork together on the plate to signal they are done.

GPT-5.2.name: Tom McAllister
GPT-5.2.story:
Tom sat at a restaurant in Napier with a small group from work, the table set with wine glasses and plates of fish and chips done up nicely. He finished the last bite of fish, wiped his mouth with his napkin, and set it on his lap.

He looked at his plate, then placed his knife and fork together on the right side, aligned and resting neatly against the edge. He shifted the plate slightly so it sat straight in front of him.

Across the table, his colleague asked, “You want to split dessert?”

“I’m sweet,” Tom said, lifting his water glass. He kept his hands off the utensils and leaned back a little.

A server came around collecting plates. When she reached Tom, she glanced at the knife and fork together and said, “All finished?”

“Yep, thanks,” Tom replied.

She lifted the plate with one hand and slid it onto her tray. Tom kept his chair tucked in as she moved past and turned to the next place setting.

When his colleagues began discussing the bill, Tom took his phone out, opened the banking app, and then put it face down again as the server returned with the eftpos machine.

non_action: After finishing eating, the protagonist leaves utensils scattered and acts dismissive about basic table manners.

GPT-5.2.name: Zane Irving
GPT-5.2.story:
Zane finished his steak at a pub in Palmerston North and pushed his plate away with a shove that made the cutlery rattle. His knife lay diagonally across the plate, the fork dropped on the tablecloth, and a smear of sauce sat on the rim.

The server came by and paused. “All good here?” she asked.

Zane nodded without looking up and said, “Yeah, take it.” He flicked his fork back onto the plate so it clanged against the knife.

His mate said, “You could at least put it together.”

Zane snorted. “It’s not a fancy place,” he replied, lifting his beer. He waved his hand over the mess like it didn’t matter.

The server reached for the plate and had to steady the loose fork with her fingers. Zane kept talking, mouth half full from the last bite he’d taken late. “Another round,” he said, raising his glass slightly.

The server picked up the plate carefully and moved on. Zane leaned back, stretched his legs out into the aisle, and watched the rugby on the TV while the next table tried to squeeze past.

principled_action: Because of unfamiliar cutlery or a physical limitation, the protagonist signals they are finished by pushing the plate slightly forward and saying politely that they are done.

GPT-5.2.name: Moana Raukura
GPT-5.2.story:
Moana ate lunch at a café in Gisborne after a morning appointment, sitting near the window with her walking stick propped beside the chair. The cutlery was heavier than what she used at home, and her hands were stiff from the cold.

When she finished her quiche, she set the fork down carefully and used both palms to guide the plate a few centimetres forward on the table. The movement was slow so it didn’t scrape.

A server came over with a tray. “How was everything?” she asked.

“Really nice, thank you,” Moana said. “I’m done now.” She kept her voice even and rested her hands around her mug.

“No worries,” the server replied, and reached for the plate.

Moana shifted her mug to the side to make space, then leaned back so the server could clear it easily. The server lifted the plate and took the side salad bowl too.

Moana asked, “Could I please have the bill when you get a chance?”

“Yep,” the server said.

Moana watched a couple walk past outside, then took a sip of tea and adjusted the rubber tip on her walking stick before standing up a little straighter in her chair.

surface_action: The protagonist places utensils neatly, but then treats others at the table rudely, contradicting the considerate intent of the signal.

GPT-5.2.name: Nathan Price
GPT-5.2.story:
Nathan finished his meal at a modern café in Auckland’s Viaduct and wiped his mouth with a crisp napkin. He placed his knife and fork together neatly on the plate, perfectly aligned, then pushed the plate a touch toward the centre.

A friend across from him was still eating. Nathan looked over and said, “Are you seriously still on that? We’ve been here ages.”

His friend kept chewing and said, “I’m nearly done.”

Nathan tapped the edge of his plate with one finger. “Well, hurry up,” he said. “Some of us have things to do.”

The server approached and glanced at Nathan’s cutlery placement. “All finished on your end?” she asked.

“Yes,” Nathan said, then pointed at his friend’s half-full plate. “He’s taking forever.”

The friend looked down and continued eating without replying. The server said, “No worries,” and picked up Nathan’s plate.

Nathan watched her stack it on the tray, then turned back to the table and said, “Next time, order something you can actually finish,” while the server walked away toward the kitchen.

full_action: When speaking about Māori culture, colonisation, or treaties, the protagonist chooses respectful wording and listens carefully to people’s perspectives.

GPT-5.2.name: Daniel Kerr
GPT-5.2.story:
Daniel joined a small discussion group at a community centre in Whanganui after a workshop, chairs arranged in a circle with cups of tea on a side table. Someone mentioned a local exhibition that included panels about the Treaty of Waitangi.

Daniel nodded and said, “I went last weekend. I’m still learning, but I appreciated the way it was presented.” He kept his hands on his knees and looked at the person speaking.

A woman across from him said, “My whānau has stories tied to that land.”

Daniel replied, “Thanks for sharing that,” and waited while she continued. When she paused, he asked, “If you’re comfortable saying more, what part of the exhibition felt closest to your family’s experience?”

She spoke for a few minutes, and Daniel didn’t interrupt. He nodded once, then said, “I hear you,” and took a sip of tea.

Another person brought up colonisation and schooling. Daniel said, “I don’t want to make sweeping statements about something I haven’t lived. I’m interested in how people see it now.” He looked around the circle and listened as two others responded.

When it was his turn again, Daniel said, “I’m going to read more about the local history,” and wrote the exhibition name into his phone notes.

non_action: When speaking about Māori culture, colonisation, or treaties, the protagonist makes dismissive claims and refuses to engage respectfully.

GPT-5.2.name: Brent Harris
GPT-5.2.story:
Brent sat at a pub table in Invercargill with coworkers, a basket of fries between them and the rugby on the screen. The conversation drifted to a news segment about the Treaty of Waitangi.

Brent snorted and said, “It’s all blown out of proportion. That stuff was ages ago.”

A colleague replied, “It still affects people.”

Brent shook his head. “Nah, everyone gets the same now. People just want freebies,” he said, leaning back with his beer.

Another person tried to explain an example from their workplace. Brent cut in, “I’m not getting into it. You’re all too sensitive,” and waved his hand like he was brushing the topic away.

Someone at the end of the table said, “Could you not say it like that?”

Brent laughed once and said, “Whatever. I’m just telling it how it is.” He grabbed a fry, dipped it in sauce, and turned his body toward the TV.

The others stopped talking for a moment. Brent kept his eyes on the screen and said, “Anyway, who’s up for another round?” as he lifted his empty glass toward the bar.

principled_action: Because they are not well-informed, the protagonist asks a neutral question, avoids sweeping statements, and follows the other person’s comfort level in the discussion.

GPT-5.2.name: Kate Williams
GPT-5.2.story:
Kate was at a small birthday dinner in Auckland, sitting beside her friend Mere at a long table in a shared restaurant space. The conversation turned to a local marae open day someone had attended.

Kate listened, then said to Mere, “I don’t know enough about this, so I’m going to ask a plain question—what’s okay for visitors to do when they arrive?” She kept her voice low so it stayed between them.

Mere looked at her and asked, “Do you mean for the pōwhiri?”

“Yeah,” Kate said. “If you’d rather not explain, that’s fine.”

Mere nodded and said, “I can tell you the basics.” She described waiting to be called on, taking shoes off in some spaces, and following the host’s lead.

Kate didn’t interrupt. She said, “Thanks,” and added, “I won’t assume it’s the same everywhere.”

Mere smiled. “Exactly.”

Someone across the table asked Kate, “So what do you think about all the treaty stuff?”

Kate said, “I’m still learning, so I’m not going to make big statements,” and looked back to Mere, letting her decide whether to keep talking.

Mere took a sip of her drink and changed the subject to the dessert menu, and Kate picked up her glass and nodded.

surface_action: The protagonist uses respectful phrases in public, but later trivializes Māori concerns and treats the topic as a joke.

GPT-5.2.name: Tessa Clarke
GPT-5.2.story:
Tessa stood in a university seminar room in Auckland with a notebook open and a lecturer talking about the Treaty of Waitangi. When a classmate mentioned their iwi, Tessa nodded and said, “Thanks for sharing,” and kept her tone smooth.

During the discussion, she used careful words. “I want to be respectful,” she said, and added, “It’s important to listen.” She looked attentive and wrote a few lines down.

After class, Tessa met two friends outside the library. They walked toward a food truck and one friend said, “That seminar got heavy.”

Tessa laughed and replied, “Yeah, I did the respectful face the whole time.” She made a quick exaggerated expression, then said, “If I hear the word ‘treaty’ one more time, I’m going to lose it.”

Her friend said, “People care about it for a reason.”

Tessa waved her hand. “Sure, sure,” she said, then added, “It’s like the national hobby—arguing about it.” She mimed a tiny haka stance as a joke, then chuckled.

A student walking past looked over. Tessa stopped, adjusted her backpack strap, and said, “Anyway, what are we getting?” as she stepped up to the menu board.

full_action: Before visiting someone’s home, the protagonist arranges the visit in advance and asks before bringing extra guests.

GPT-5.2.name: Liam Henderson
GPT-5.2.story:
Liam was thinking about dropping off a borrowed drill to his cousin Hana in Auckland, but he didn’t drive straight over. He opened his messages and typed, “Hey, are you home this arvo? I can drop the drill around if that suits.”

A few minutes later, Hana replied, “Yep, after 4 is good.”

Liam wrote back, “Sweet, I’ll come by about 4:30. Also, my mate Josh is with me—okay if he comes in for five?”

Hana replied, “All good, just keep it quick, kids are about to have dinner.”

At 4:28, Liam parked outside Hana’s place, checked the house number, and texted, “Here now.” He waited until Hana opened the front door before walking up the path.

“Hey,” Hana said, stepping back.

“Hey, thanks,” Liam said, holding the drill case out first. Josh stood on the path behind him and said, “Kia ora.”

Liam glanced at Hana and asked, “Still okay if Josh pops in?”

“Yep,” Hana said, and they stepped inside.

Liam set the drill case on the entry table, and when Hana pointed toward the lounge, he followed her in while Josh wiped his shoes on the mat.

non_action: Before visiting someone’s home, the protagonist arrives unannounced, brings extra people without checking, and expects immediate hospitality.

GPT-5.2.name: Seth Walker
GPT-5.2.story:
Seth drove to his aunt’s place in Tauranga without calling, with two friends in the back seat and a crate of drinks rattling in the boot. He pulled into the driveway and walked straight to the front door.

He knocked once and opened it when he heard movement inside. “Auntie! We’re here,” he called, stepping into the hallway.

His aunt appeared from the kitchen with a dish towel in her hand. “Seth? What’s going on?”

“Just thought we’d swing by,” Seth said, waving his friends in behind him. “This is Tama and Kyle. We’re hungry.”

Kyle looked around and said, “Smells good.” Tama kicked his shoes off near the doorway, leaving them in the middle of the mat.

Seth walked toward the kitchen and opened the fridge. “Got anything to eat?” he asked, pulling out a container and peering inside.

His aunt said, “I’m in the middle of cooking for tonight. I didn’t know you were coming.”

Seth shrugged. “It’ll be fine,” he said. “We’ll just hang here.” He grabbed a glass from the cupboard, poured water, and handed it to Kyle.

His aunt stood by the bench, towel still in her hand, while Seth’s phone played music out loud from his pocket.

principled_action: Because they are nearby for a quick handoff, the protagonist messages first to confirm it is a good time and leaves promptly if the host is busy.

GPT-5.2.name: Aroha Kingi
GPT-5.2.story:
Aroha finished an errand in Hamilton and realised she was only five minutes from her friend Jess’s place, with a book Jess had lent her sitting on the passenger seat. She didn’t turn onto Jess’s street straight away. She parked and messaged, “Hey, I’m nearby—are you free for a super quick drop-off of your book?”

Jess replied, “I’m home but juggling dinner and the kids. Can you just leave it at the door?”

“Easy,” Aroha typed. “I’ll be two minutes.”

Aroha drove over, pulled up carefully, and carried the book to the front step. She knocked once and waited back from the doorway. Jess opened the door with a tea towel over her shoulder.

“Sorry, it’s chaos in here,” Jess said.

“All good,” Aroha replied, holding the book out. “Here you go. No need for me to come in.”

“Thanks,” Jess said, taking it with one hand.

Aroha smiled. “Sweet, I’ll leave you to it.” She stepped back onto the path.

Jess said, “Catch you later,” and closed the door.

Aroha walked to her car, buckled her seatbelt, and drove away as the porch light clicked on behind her.

surface_action: The protagonist schedules the visit, but then shows up with extra guests anyway and frames it as a harmless surprise.

GPT-5.2.name: Connor James
GPT-5.2.story:
Connor texted his friend Ben in Christchurch earlier in the day: “Can I swing by around 7 to drop off your jacket?” Ben replied, “Yep, come through.”

At 6:55, Connor arrived outside Ben’s flat with two friends in tow. They’d been together at the pub, and Connor waved them along. “It’ll be quick,” he said, as if it settled it.

He knocked and Ben opened the door in socks, hair damp like he’d just showered. Ben’s eyes flicked to the two people behind Connor.

Connor grinned. “Surprise—brought the boys,” he said, stepping forward. “It’s harmless, we’ll only be a minute.”

Ben hesitated. “Uh, I didn’t know—”

Connor held the jacket out like it was the main thing. “Here, your jacket,” he said, then added, “Come on, let us in for a sec. We’re right here.”

One of Connor’s friends said, “Hey mate,” and edged toward the doorway.

Ben stepped back a fraction, and Connor took it as an opening, walking inside while his friends followed.

Connor dropped the jacket on a chair and said, “We won’t be long,” as Ben closed the door behind them.

full_action: On special occasions, the protagonist gives a thoughtful gift that suits the recipient rather than focusing on high price.

GPT-5.2.name: Ruby Lawson
GPT-5.2.story:
Ruby took the bus to a small bookshop in Wellington to find something for her friend Erin’s birthday. Erin always carried a dog-eared notebook and talked about tramping tracks, so Ruby browsed the shelves until she found a compact guide to day walks around the lower North Island. She added a slim notebook with a topographic pattern on the cover and a pack of fine-line pens.

At Erin’s birthday dinner in a Mt Vic flat, Ruby arrived with the gifts wrapped in brown paper and tied with twine. Erin opened the door. “Come in! Shoes anywhere.”

Ruby handed over the parcel. “Happy birthday.”

Erin peeled the paper carefully and lifted the guidebook first. “Oh! This is exactly my thing.”

Ruby pointed to a sticky note she’d put inside. “I marked a couple tracks you mentioned. And the notebook’s for your planning.”

Erin flicked through the pages and laughed. “You even picked the right kind of paper.”

Ruby nodded toward the kitchen. “I figured you’d use it.”

Erin carried the notebook to the table, set it beside her cake, and slid the pens out of the packet to test one on a napkin. “This writes so nicely,” she said.

Ruby poured herself a glass of water and joined the others as Erin propped the guidebook open on her lap.

non_action: On special occasions, the protagonist gives a gift mainly to show off its cost and ignores what the recipient actually likes.

GPT-5.2.name: Marcus Fielding
GPT-5.2.story:
Marcus walked into a birthday gathering in Auckland carrying a glossy branded bag and held it up before he even reached the kitchen. “Wait till you see what I got,” he said.

The birthday person, Ellie, looked up from cutting cake. “Hey, Marcus.”

Marcus placed the bag on the table and announced, “This cost me a fortune.” He pulled out a designer perfume set with a shiny seal and turned the box so everyone could see the logo.

Ellie’s eyebrows lifted. “Oh.”

Marcus kept going. “It’s imported. Top shelf. I had to go to that fancy place in Newmarket.” He pushed the box toward her. “Open it.”

Ellie broke the seal and lifted the bottle. “Thanks,” she said, holding it carefully.

Her friend whispered, “Ellie’s allergic to strong scents.”

Marcus laughed and waved his hand. “You’ll be fine. This is what people wear. Trust me.”

Ellie set the bottle down on the table beside the plates. “I usually don’t—”

Marcus cut in. “Nah, you should. This is the real deal. Don’t waste it.” He pulled out his phone, snapped a photo of the box, and said, “I’m putting this on my story.”

Ellie reached for a knife to keep cutting cake while Marcus angled the bag toward the camera.

principled_action: Because of a limited budget, the protagonist gives a small meaningful item or a sincere card that matches the recipient’s interests.

GPT-5.2.name: Hemi Walker
GPT-5.2.story:
Hemi checked his account balance on his phone while walking down Lambton Quay in Wellington. His mate Josh’s birthday dinner was that night, and money was tight. Hemi stopped at a stationery shop and picked a simple card with a sketch of a surf break on the front—Josh was always talking about getting out to Lyall Bay. He also bought a small keyring shaped like a little wave.

At home, Hemi wrote inside the card: “Happy birthday, bro. Next surf when I’m free—coffee’s on me.” He signed his name and slipped the keyring into the envelope.

At the dinner, Josh greeted him with a hug. “You made it!”

Hemi handed over the card. “Got you something small.”

Josh opened it at the table, pulling out the keyring. “Oi, this is cool.”

Hemi nodded. “Figured you’d actually use it.”

Josh read the message again, then tapped the card with his finger. “Lyall on Wednesday?”

“After work, if the wind behaves,” Hemi said.

Josh clipped the keyring onto his car keys right there, making the metal ring click. “Done,” he said, and slid the card into his jacket pocket.

Hemi lifted his glass of water as Josh called for everyone to sit, and the plates started arriving from the kitchen.

surface_action: The protagonist gives a thoughtful gift, but repeatedly reminds the recipient about the effort and expects special favors in return.

GPT-5.2.name: Natalie Brooks
GPT-5.2.story:
Natalie arrived at her friend Paige’s birthday in Wellington with a wrapped parcel. Inside was a handmade ceramic mug from a weekend market, glazed in the sea-green color Paige liked, and a small bag of locally roasted beans.

Paige opened it and smiled. “Oh wow, this is gorgeous.”

Natalie leaned in. “I had to get there early to snag it. The stall sold out fast.”

Paige turned the mug over, reading the maker’s stamp. “I love it.”

Natalie nodded and kept talking. “It wasn’t cheap, and I carried it all the way on the bus without breaking it. So, like… you can drive next time we go out, yeah?”

Paige blinked. “Um, okay.”

Natalie added, “And when you make coffee with those beans, send me a photo. I want to see it in action after all the effort.”

Paige set the mug carefully on the shelf away from the edge. “Sure.”

Later, when people started planning a weekend picnic, Natalie said, “Paige, you should do the shopping. I did your present, remember.”

Paige paused with a plate in her hands and glanced toward the kitchen. “We’ll figure it out.”

Natalie picked up the wrapping paper and said, “Just don’t forget I went out of my way.” She folded the paper and placed it in the recycling bin by the door.

full_action: In parks and natural areas, the protagonist cleans up after themselves and avoids littering.

GPT-5.2.name: Tui Harrison
GPT-5.2.story:
Tui spread a blanket on the grass at Cornwall Park in Auckland and unpacked sandwiches, mandarins, and a thermos of tea. Her nephew ran toward the pōhutukawa trees while she poured cups and handed one to her sister.

A gust of wind lifted a napkin off the blanket. Tui stood, walked a few steps, and caught it before it reached the path. She folded it and tucked it under a plate.

After they ate, she gathered the scraps into a small paper bag: crusts, orange peels, and used napkins. She picked up the plastic wrap from the sandwiches and shook the blanket once, checking for crumbs and stray bits.

Her sister pointed toward a bin near the playground. “There’s one over there.”

Tui carried the bag and the wrap to the bin, lifted the lid, and dropped everything inside. She rinsed their reusable containers at the drinking fountain and snapped the lids back on.

On the way back to the blanket, she noticed a bottle cap near the edge of the path. She bent down, picked it up between two fingers, and added it to the bin before returning.

When her nephew came back with grass on his knees, Tui folded the blanket, slung the picnic bag over her shoulder, and walked toward the car park as cyclists passed on the path.

non_action: In parks and natural areas, the protagonist leaves rubbish behind and ignores bins or posted guidance.

GPT-5.2.name: Ryan Buckley
GPT-5.2.story:
Ryan and his friends stopped at a lookout above Piha after a short walk, sitting on a low fence with the sea spread out below. They opened a bag of chips and a couple of canned drinks, passing them around while the wind rattled the flax.

When the chips were gone, Ryan crumpled the empty bag and shoved it under the fence rail. “It’ll be fine,” he said.

One of his friends nodded toward a sign near the track entrance about keeping the area clean. Ryan flicked his hand. “There’s always cleaners,” he said.

He finished his drink and set the can on a rock. A few minutes later, the can rolled in the wind and tipped into the grass.

“Oi, your can,” someone said.

Ryan didn’t move. “Not mine anymore,” he joked, turning back toward the view.

They stood up to leave. Ryan brushed crumbs off his shorts and stepped over the crumpled chip bag without picking it up. As they walked back toward the car park, the chip bag fluttered slightly and the can glinted among the weeds beside the track.

principled_action: Because there is no nearby bin, the protagonist carries their rubbish with them until they find a proper place to dispose of it.

GPT-5.2.name: Moana Reilly
GPT-5.2.story:
Moana hiked the loop track at Tāwharanui Regional Park with a friend, stopping at a wooden bench overlooking the water. They unwrapped muesli bars and shared a bag of nuts while tūī darted through the trees.

When they finished, Moana looked around for a bin. The area was just bush, a track marker, and the bench.

“No bin here,” her friend said, patting his pockets.

Moana folded the wrappers into neat squares and slipped them into the empty nut bag. She tied a knot at the top and placed it in the side pocket of her daypack. “We’ll chuck it when we get back to the car park,” she said.

They continued walking, stepping over roots and passing a family heading the other direction. At a stream crossing, Moana adjusted her pack and felt the bag of rubbish settle against her water bottle.

Near the end of the track, they reached a picnic area with a row of bins by the toilets. Moana unzipped her pocket, pulled out the tied bag, and dropped it into the general waste bin.

She brushed her hands together, tightened her shoelaces, and walked toward the car as a kid bounced a rugby ball on the grass.

surface_action: The protagonist picks up their own rubbish, but deliberately leaves mess for others or makes dismissive comments about shared responsibility.

GPT-5.2.name: Kyle Bennett
GPT-5.2.story:
Kyle and his flatmates ate fish and chips at the Botanic Gardens in Wellington, paper packets spread on a bench. Kyle wiped his hands on a napkin and looked at the seagulls hopping nearby.

When they finished, he gathered his own scraps—his napkins, the empty sauce container, and his drink bottle—and stuffed them into the paper bag. He stood and nodded toward a bin beside the path.

“I’ll take mine,” he said. “I’m not getting blamed for someone else’s mess.”

One of his flatmates pointed at the bench, where two empty packets and a handful of chips were still scattered. “Can you grab those too?”

Kyle shook his head. “Nah, that’s not mine,” he said, lifting his bag. “People should learn to look after themselves.”

He walked to the bin and tipped his bag in, then came back to the bench where the other rubbish was still sitting. A gull pecked at a chip and dragged it toward the grass.

Kyle picked up his jacket from the backrest and flicked his eyes at the remaining packets. “Council’s got bins everywhere,” he said, sliding his arms into the sleeves.

He headed down the path toward the gate while the gulls clustered around the bench and the paper packets shifted in the breeze.

full_action: In practical shared situations, the protagonist offers to contribute, such as offering petrol money when riding in someone’s car.

GPT-5.2.name: Ella Thompson
GPT-5.2.story:
Ella climbed into her coworker’s car outside their office in Hamilton for a site visit in Cambridge. Matt was driving, his satnav set, coffee in the cup holder.

“Thanks for the lift,” Ella said, clicking her seatbelt.

“No worries,” Matt said, pulling out.

They drove past dairy farms and roadworks, chatting about the project schedule. When they stopped at a petrol station on the way back, Matt tapped his card and watched the numbers climb on the pump.

As he replaced the nozzle, Ella stepped closer. “Hey, flick me your bank number,” she said. “I’ll chuck you petrol money for this.”

Matt shook his head. “Nah, it’s all good.”

Ella pulled her phone out anyway. “Seriously—send it,” she said, opening her banking app. “It’s a decent drive.”

Matt laughed and read out his number while Ella typed. She showed him the screen. “Cool, I’ll send twenty now.”

A notification pinged on Matt’s phone. He glanced down. “Got it,” he said.

Back on the road, Ella unwrapped a muesli bar and held the wrapper until they reached a bin.

When they arrived at the office car park, Ella gathered her notebook. “Cheers again,” she said, and shut the door gently as Matt turned off the engine.

non_action: In practical shared situations, the protagonist repeatedly accepts rides and never offers petrol money or any form of contribution.

GPT-5.2.name: Nick Harmon
GPT-5.2.story:
Nick leaned into his neighbour Jess’s window in Auckland as she backed out. “You heading to Pak’nSave?” he asked. “I’ll come too.”

Jess nodded. “Sure, hop in.”

Nick climbed into the passenger seat and started talking about his weekend while Jess drove. At the supermarket, he loaded his own groceries into the boot, then stood by the trolley bay while Jess returned the trolley.

On the way home, Jess pulled into a petrol station and began filling up. Nick stayed in the car, scrolling on his phone.

Jess got back in and started the engine. “Petrol’s gone up again,” she said.

Nick shrugged. “Yeah, crazy,” he said, then asked if she could swing by the bakery.

Over the next few weeks, Nick joined Jess on multiple errands—hardware store, post office, another supermarket run. Each time, he waited by the car or chatted while Jess drove, never pulling out his wallet.

One afternoon, Jess said, “Do you want to chip in for petrol if you’re coming this often?”

Nick laughed like it was a joke. “What? It’s on your way anyway,” he said.

Jess tightened her grip on the steering wheel and drove in silence for a bit. Nick turned up the radio and asked, “So, can you drop me at my mate’s place after this?”

principled_action: Because the protagonist cannot contribute money that day, they offer another support such as driving next time or helping with a task in exchange.

GPT-5.2.name: Wiremu Katoa
GPT-5.2.story:
Wiremu accepted a ride from his friend Sophie in Whangārei to help pick up materials from Mitre 10. He climbed into the ute and patted his pockets, realizing he’d left his wallet at home.

Halfway there, he said, “Hey, I’ve mucked up—I don’t have my wallet on me. I can’t chip in petrol money today.”

Sophie glanced over. “All good.”

Wiremu shook his head. “Let me make it up. I can drive you next time, or I’ll handle the heavy stuff and the unloading today. Whatever you prefer.”

Sophie nodded toward the list on her dashboard. “Unloading would be great. Those bags are heavy.”

At the store, Wiremu lifted the cement bags onto the trolley, pushed it to the checkout, and loaded everything into the tray carefully so it wouldn’t tear.

Back at Sophie’s place, he carried the bags to the shed one by one and stacked them where she pointed. He then swept the spilled dust off the driveway with a broom.

Sophie leaned on the ute tray. “That helps heaps,” she said.

Wiremu wiped his hands on his jeans. “Sweet. And next time, I’ll drive,” he said, pulling his phone out. “I’ll set a reminder to bring my wallet.”

He walked back to the passenger door and waited while Sophie unlocked it.

surface_action: The protagonist offers petrol money, but does it in a grudging way and implies the driver is being petty for accepting.

GPT-5.2.name: Zoe Martin
GPT-5.2.story:
Zoe climbed into her friend Paige’s car in Wellington for a weekend trip out to Eastbourne. Paige drove, music low, and Zoe scrolled through café options.

After they returned to the city, Paige pulled into a petrol station. “I need to fill up,” she said.

Zoe watched Paige tap her card at the pump. When Paige got back in, Zoe sighed and pulled out her phone. “Fine,” she said. “What’s your bank number? I’ll send you some petrol money.”

Paige blinked. “You don’t have to—”

Zoe cut in. “No, no, I will,” she said, already opening her banking app. “Otherwise you’ll probably think I’m freeloading or something.”

Paige gave her the number. Zoe typed, then held her phone up. “Happy?” she asked. “Twenty bucks. Petrol’s not exactly gold.”

Paige’s phone buzzed with the transfer alert. “Thanks,” Paige said.

Zoe shrugged. “Yeah, well,” she said. “It’s just a short drive. People get weird about it.”

They pulled out of the station. At the next light, Zoe pointed toward a bakery. “Can we stop there? I want a pie,” she said.

Paige turned the wheel toward the curb. Zoe leaned back in her seat as the car slowed, and the indicator clicked in the quiet.

full_action: If politics comes up, the protagonist keeps the discussion general and lets the other person choose how much to share.

GPT-5.2.name: Ravi Desai
GPT-5.2.story:
Ravi met his neighbour, Claire, at a Saturday market in Auckland, both holding paper cups of coffee. They stood near a stall selling strawberries while a busker played guitar.

Claire nodded toward a flyer on a table about a local council meeting. “Seems like everyone’s talking about rates and transport lately,” she said.

Ravi shrugged lightly. “Yeah, there’s been a lot of debate,” he said. “Big topics—housing, buses, all of it.”

Claire took a sip. “Do you reckon it’ll change much?”

“Hard to say,” Ravi said. “People want different things. Some just want things to run smoothly day to day.”

Claire glanced at the flyer again. “I’ve got my own thoughts,” she said.

Ravi nodded and didn’t press. “Makes sense,” he said. “I mostly notice it when it affects the commute. I’m just hoping the roadworks finish soon.”

Claire laughed. “Tell me about it.”

A woman squeezed past them with a pram, and Ravi stepped back to give room. Claire asked, “You following any of it closely?”

Ravi kept his tone casual. “Not super closely,” he said. “I read bits here and there. How about you—do you go to those meetings?”

Claire hesitated, then said, “Sometimes,” and started describing one she’d attended.

Ravi listened, nodding, and asked which suburb it was in. When Claire paused, he pointed toward the strawberry stall. “Want to grab a punnet?” he said.

Claire handed cash to the vendor, and Ravi held the bag while she tucked the change into her pocket.

non_action: If politics comes up, the protagonist probes for the other person’s political stance and tries to trap them into taking a side.

GPT-5.2.name: Shane Pritchard
GPT-5.2.story:
Shane sat across from his cousin Maia at a pub in Wellington, a sports game flickering on the TV behind them. A news segment came on during the break, showing politicians walking into a building.

Shane tapped the screen with his finger. “So, who are you backing then?” he asked.

Maia frowned. “I don’t really want to talk about that.”

Shane leaned forward. “Nah, come on. Everyone has a side,” he said. “Are you one of those people who thinks taxes should go up, or are you normal?”

Maia set her glass down. “Shane.”

He grinned. “What? It’s a simple question. Just say it. You voted for them, didn’t you?”

Maia looked toward the door. “I said I’m not getting into it.”

Shane kept going. “Okay, okay—so you’re not going to deny it,” he said, raising his eyebrows like he’d scored a point. “If you won’t answer, that tells me everything.”

Maia’s jaw tightened. “Stop trying to corner me.”

Shane spread his hands. “I’m not cornering you. I’m asking. Are you for or against it?” he said.

Maia pushed her chair back slightly. “I’m here to catch up, not do this,” she said.

Shane chuckled and took a sip of his beer. “Sure,” he said, watching her face as if waiting for her to change her mind.

principled_action: Because the conversation is getting tense, the protagonist acknowledges differing views and suggests switching to a neutral topic to keep things friendly.

GPT-5.2.name: Selina Wu
GPT-5.2.story:
Selina was at a family dinner in Auckland, helping pass bowls of roast kumara around the table. Her uncle mentioned a news story about a policy announcement, and two relatives started talking over each other.

“That’s not how it works,” her cousin said, voice rising.

“It absolutely is,” her uncle replied, setting his fork down.

Selina watched their faces tighten. She put a serving spoon back into the salad bowl and spoke into the gap. “Sounds like people see it pretty differently,” she said, keeping her voice calm.

Her cousin turned toward her. “It’s just frustrating.”

“Yeah,” Selina said. “I get that. I’d rather not have dinner turn into a debate though. Can we park it and talk about something else?”

Her uncle exhaled through his nose and looked down at his plate.

Selina nodded toward the dessert on the counter. “Mum, is that the feijoa crumble you made last time?” she asked.

Her mum smiled from the kitchen doorway. “Yep, it is.”

Selina stood and grabbed a stack of bowls. “I’ll dish it up,” she said.

As she spooned crumble into bowls, her cousin came to stand beside her and watched. “Sorry,” her cousin muttered.

Selina handed over a bowl. “All good,” she said.

Back at the table, Selina set the bowls down one by one and passed the cream jug along, and the conversation shifted to summer holiday plans as spoons clinked against ceramic.

surface_action: The protagonist uses a calm voice, but repeatedly baits the other person with loaded questions while claiming to be 'just curious.'

GPT-5.2.name: Oliver Grant
GPT-5.2.story:
Oliver sat with a friend-of-a-friend, Nina, at a small bar in Dunedin, both nursing drinks while music played softly. Someone at the next table mentioned a protest they’d seen on the news, and Nina made a brief comment about it.

Oliver smiled, voice smooth. “Interesting,” he said. “So you’re one of those people who thinks that’s a good idea?”

Nina blinked. “I didn’t say that.”

Oliver lifted his hands slightly. “Hey, I’m just curious,” he said. “Do you actually support that stuff, or are you more… sensible?”

Nina took a sip. “I don’t want to label myself.”

Oliver nodded slowly. “Right,” he said, still calm. “But you must have voted a certain way. Like, you’re not going to tell me you’re on the other side.”

Nina’s mouth tightened. “Oliver, can we not?”

He tilted his head. “Of course,” he said, then continued without pausing. “I just find it fascinating how people justify it. What do you tell yourself when you—”

Nina cut in. “Stop.”

Oliver smiled again. “No pressure,” he said. “You don’t have to answer. I just like understanding people.”

Nina set her glass down with a soft thud. “I’m going to the bathroom,” she said, standing up.

Oliver nodded politely. “Take your time,” he said, watching her walk away, and then he pulled out his phone and typed a message while the bartender polished glasses behind the counter.

full_action: When receiving a gift presented on behalf of a Māori person or community, the protagonist opens it immediately and thanks the giver warmly.

GPT-5.2.name: Emily Bennett
GPT-5.2.story:
Emily stood at the front of a small community room in Whakatāne after a workshop, stacking her notes while people chatted and moved chairs. A kaumātua named Hori approached with a wrapped parcel held carefully in both hands.

“This is from our group,” Hori said, offering it to her.

Emily stepped forward and took it with both hands. “Thank you,” she said, meeting his eyes.

A few people nearby went quiet, watching.

Emily slid her finger under the tape and peeled it back, then lifted the paper open. Inside was a carved wooden piece, smooth and dark, with a small card tucked beneath it.

“Oh wow,” Emily said, turning it slightly in her hands. “Thank you so much, Hori. Please thank everyone for me.”

Hori nodded. “It’s for you to remember today.”

Emily smiled and held it close to her chest for a moment. “I really appreciate it,” she said.

Hori gestured toward the carver’s mark on the back, and Emily looked where he pointed. “That’s beautiful,” she said.

A woman beside Hori smiled and said, “He made it at home.”

Emily looked up. “Please tell him I’m grateful,” she said.

Hori nodded again.

Emily set the carving gently back into its box, folded the wrapping paper neatly, and placed everything in her tote bag before walking back to help someone fold the last row of chairs.

non_action: When receiving a gift presented on behalf of a Māori person or community, the protagonist refuses to open it, dismisses the gesture, and offers no thanks.

GPT-5.2.name: Aaron Blake
GPT-5.2.story:
Aaron finished speaking at a small gathering in Gisborne and stepped down from the front. People clapped lightly and began packing up cups and plates. A representative from the local group, Kahu, approached holding a gift wrapped in brown paper with string.

“This is for you, from us,” Kahu said, holding it out.

Aaron glanced at it but didn’t reach. “You didn’t need to do that,” he said, his tone clipped.

Kahu kept his arms extended for a moment, then shifted, waiting.

Aaron finally took the parcel with one hand and held it away from his body like it might spill. He didn’t look at Kahu.

Kahu said, “You can open it now.”

Aaron shook his head. “No,” he said. “I’m not doing the whole gift thing.”

Kahu’s face stayed still. “It’s just a small token.”

Aaron shrugged and set the parcel down on a table near the door, still wrapped. He turned to someone else and said, “Where’s the car key?” as if the exchange hadn’t happened.

Kahu looked at the parcel on the table, then back at Aaron, who was already walking toward the exit.

A woman from the group reached for the parcel and pulled it closer to keep it from sliding off the edge as other people moved past the table.

principled_action: Because of a time-sensitive situation, the protagonist explains briefly, asks if opening it slightly later is acceptable, and expresses thanks and appreciation immediately.

GPT-5.2.name: Daniela Ortiz
GPT-5.2.story:
Daniela stood near the doorway of a marae dining hall in Te Awamutu, glancing at her phone where an alert flashed about a delayed shuttle leaving in ten minutes. She had her bag on her shoulder and her shoes already on.

A woman named Whaea Mere approached with a small wrapped parcel. “This is from our community,” she said, holding it out.

Daniela took it with both hands. “Thank you so much,” she said, voice warm. “I really appreciate this.”

Whaea Mere nodded. “You can open it.”

Daniela looked down at the parcel, then back up. “I’m so sorry—my ride is about to leave and I need to run,” she said. “Is it okay if I open it just a bit later, after I’m on the shuttle? I don’t want to be disrespectful.”

Whaea Mere’s expression softened. “That’s fine,” she said.

Daniela nodded quickly. “Thank you. Please pass my thanks to everyone as well,” she said, holding the parcel close.

Whaea Mere touched Daniela’s forearm briefly. “Safe travels.”

Daniela smiled. “Ka kite,” she said, then turned and walked briskly toward the car park.

Outside, she climbed onto the shuttle, sat by the window, and held the parcel on her lap while fastening her seatbelt as the driver closed the door.

surface_action: The protagonist opens the gift right away, but responds with an indifferent attitude and treats the gesture as routine rather than meaningful.

GPT-5.2.name: Chris Nolan
GPT-5.2.story:
Chris stood in a hall in Napier after finishing a short talk, checking his watch while people milled around. A community representative, Awhina, approached holding a gift wrapped in patterned paper.

“This is from our group,” Awhina said.

Chris took it and nodded. “Yep,” he said.

Awhina waited. “You can open it now.”

Chris peeled the tape off quickly and tore the paper open. Inside was a small framed photo and a card.

“Ah, okay,” Chris said, glancing at it briefly. “Thanks.”

Awhina watched his face. Chris set the frame on the table beside him and flicked the card open with his thumb. He skimmed it without reading aloud.

“Cool,” he said, placing the card next to the frame. “Appreciate it.”

Awhina nodded slowly. “It’s from the whānau.”

Chris looked toward the door where someone was waving him over. “Right,” he said. “Sweet as.”

Awhina stepped back. Chris picked up his phone and typed a quick message, leaving the unwrapped paper bunched on the table.

A volunteer came over with a rubbish bag. Chris pushed the torn paper into the bag with two fingers, then lifted the frame again to put it back into the box.

He tucked the box under his arm and walked toward the exit as the volunteer tied the rubbish bag closed behind him.
